body.p: My visit to Manchester will so very hurried, that I have declined Mr Heywood’sJames Heywood (1810-97), FRS and FSA 1839; founder of Manchester Athenaeum, 28 Oct 35, and first President; trustee of Owens College 1845-60; MP for North Lancs 1847-57. CD met him at Manchester in 1843 extremely kind Invitation. I regret the cause very much, but it is really a relief to me be free. Mr JerroldDouglas Jerrold (1803-57), dramatist, radical journalist and wit; author of over 60 plays, including his most famous, Black-eyed Susan (1829). He was one of CD’s closest friends. Edited Douglas Jerrold’s Shilling Magazine and Douglas Jerrold’s Weekly Newspaper. and I purpose coming downCD had planned to travel to Manchester with Jerrold and John Leech to attend a meeting of the Athenaeum there on 22 October, but abandoned the plan on account of the advanced state of Catherine’s pregnancy; she gave birth to Alfred D’Orsay Tennyson Dickens on 28 October. together on the Wednesday Evening; and we shall leave on the Morning after the Soirée. Pray do not think of having anyone waiting at the Railway, as we shall drive straight to our hotel and be quite at home.
